thread.title: Rookie blocked from making Supercars debut
thread.title_full: Rookie blocked from making Supercars debut

title: Rookie blocked from making Supercars debut
text:
Supercars: Matt Chahda denied chance to race second Lucas Dumbrell Motorsport car in 2017 February 9, 2017 3:09pm Source: FOX SPORTS SUPERCARS hopeful Matt Chahda has been blocked from making his championship debut in 2017. 
Chahda has been announced as the driver of the second Lucas Dumbrell Motorsport entry at the Supercars season launch at the Adelaide Oval, where he was to join 16-year-old rookie Alex Rullo. 
Chahda has spent the past two seasons racing in the second-tier Dunlop Series, his best race result an 11th in the final round at Homebush last year on his way to 20th in the championship. 
Chahda’s bid to race in the championship has been blocked by the Confederation of Australian Motor Sport, motorsport’s national governing body. 
Similar to Rullo, Chahda doesn’t meet the minimum requirements to qualify for the CAMS Superlicence needed to be eligible to race in Supercars, having not earnt the minimum 13 Superlicence points from results across his past five seasons of racing. 
Rullo applied for and was granted a special dispensation by CAMS to attain a provisional Superlicence, with his on-track behaivour to be monitored at each event. 
Chahda was not so fortunate. 
CAMS released a statement just minutes after Chahda stepped off the stage with the 2017 cohort confirming that it had refused his application on Wednesday afternoon. 
Andre Heimgartner is now the likely candidate to take up the second seat at LDM for the 2017 season. 
STATEMENT FROM CAMS The Confederation of Australian Motor Sport (CAMS) has refused a dispensation for a Superlicence by Matt Chahda for the 2017 Supercars Championship season. This was communicated to his team yesterday afternoon. 
In considering whether to grant the dispensation, CAMS is required to satisfy itself that there are exceptional circumstances to support a decision to waive the minimum requirements. CAMS has determined that there are no exceptional circumstances to support a decision to waive the minimum requirements. It is the opinion of CAMS that Matt Chahda has not demonstrated the necessary driving skill and competency to support the dispensation requested. 
CAMS values the safety of competitors, officials and fans above all other considerations. 
Matt Chahda has been announced as the driver of the second Lucas Dumbrell Motorsport entry at the Supercars season launch at the Adelaide Oval, where he will join 16-year-old rookie Alex Rullo. 
Chahda has spent the past two seasons racing in the second-tier Dunlop Series, his best race result an 11th in the final round at Homebush last year on his way to 20th in the championship. 
However, Chahda’s acceptance as a Supercars driver has yet to be fully confirmed. 
Similar to his teammate Rullo, Chahda doesn’t meet the minimum requirements to qualify for the CAMS Superlicence needed to be eligible to race in Supercars, having not earnt the minimum 13 Superlicence points from results across his past five seasons of racing. 
While Chahda joined the other 25 drivers that make up the class of 2017 on stage in Adelaide, it remains to be seen if he will receive the same special dispensation that Rullo has received. 
CAMS has been contacted for comment. View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
